abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec><jats:title>Background</jats:title><jats:p>Tobacco smoking induces immunomodulatory and pro-inflammatory effects associated with transcriptome changes in monocytes and other immune cell types. While smoking is prevalent in HIV-infected (HIV+) individuals, few studies have investigated its effects on gene expression in this population. Here, we report whole-transcriptome analyses of 125 peripheral blood monocyte samples from ART-treated HIV+ and uninfected (HIV−) men enrolled in the Multicenter AIDS Cohort Study (MACS) (<jats:italic>n =</jats:italic>25 HIV+ smokers,<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>= 60 HIV+ non-smokers,<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>= 40 HIV− non-smoking controls). Gene expression profiling was performed using Illumina HumanHT-12 Expression BeadChip microarrays. Differential expression analysis was performed with weighted linear regression models using the R<jats:italic>limma</jats:italic>package, followed by functional enrichment and Ingenuity Pathway analyses.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Results</jats:title><jats:p>A total of 286 genes were differentially expressed in monocytes from HIV+ smokers compared with HIV− non-smokers; upregulated genes (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>= 180) were enriched for immune and interferon response, chemical/stress response, mitochondria, and extracellular vesicle gene ontology (GO) terms. Expression of genes related to immune/interferon responses (<jats:italic>AIM2</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>FCGR1A-B</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>IFI16</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>SP100</jats:italic>), stress/chemical responses (<jats:italic>APAF1</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>HSPD1</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>KLF4</jats:italic>), and mitochondrial function (<jats:italic>CISD1</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>MTHFD2</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>SQOR</jats:italic>) was upregulated in HIV+ non-smokers and further increased in HIV+ smokers. Gene expression changes associated with smoking in previous studies of human monocytes were also observed (<jats:italic>SASH1</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>STAB1</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>PID1</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>MMP25</jats:italic>). Depressive symptoms (CES-D scores ≥ 16) were more prevalent in HIV+ tobacco smokers compared with HIV+ and HIV− non-smokers (50% vs. 26% and 13%, respectively;<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>= 0.007), and upregulation of immune/interferon response genes, including<jats:italic>IFI35</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>IFNAR1</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>OAS1-2</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>STAT1</jats:italic>, and<jats:italic>SP100</jats:italic>, was associated with depressive symptoms in logistic regression models adjusted for HIV status and smoking (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic>< 0.05). Network models linked the Stat1-mediated interferon pathway to transcriptional regulator Klf4 and smoking-associated toll-like receptor scaffolding protein Sash1, suggesting inter-relationships between smoking-associated genes, control of monocyte differentiation, and interferon-mediated inflammatory responses.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title><jats:p>This study characterizes immune, interferon, stress response, and mitochondrial-associated gene expression changes in monocytes from HIV+ tobacco smokers, and identifies augmented interferon and stress responses associated with depressive symptoms. These findings help to explain complex interrelationships between pro-inflammatory effects of HIV and smoking, and their combined impact on comorbidities prevalent in HIV+ individuals.</jats:p></jats:sec>

title: Transcriptomic analysis of monocytes from HIV-positive men on antiretroviral therapy reveals effects of tobacco smoking on interferon and stress response systems associated with depressive symptoms
